pages:
Technical Assistance Report
 
Project Number: 44095-01 
Regional—Research and Development Technical Assistance (R–RDTA) 
August 2010 
 
 
Assessment of Impediments and Actions  
Required for Achieving an ASEAN Economic 
Community by 2015 
  
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
AEC  –  ASEAN economic community 
ASEAN  –  Association of Southeast Asian Nations  
ISEAS  –  Institute of Southeast Asian Studies  
TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Regional—Research and development technical assistance  
(R–RDTA) 
Targeting classification  –  General intervention 
Sectors (subsectors)  –  Industry and trade (trade and services), public sector management  
(economic and public affairs management) 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Regional cooperation and integration (trade and investments); 
economic growth (promoting macroeconomic stability, widening 
access to markets and economic opportunities) 
Location impact  –  Rural (low), urban (medium), national (high), regional (high)  
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to US dollars. 
 
 
Head  S. Madhur, Senior Director and Officer-in-Charge, Office of Regional 
Economic Integration (OREI) 
   
Team leader  J. Menon, Principal Economist, OREI 
Team member  W. Paz, Senior Economics Officer, OREI 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  At  the  Ninth  ASEAN  (Association  of  Southeast  Asian  Nations)  Summit  in  Bali  on  
7 October 2003, the ASEAN leaders agreed to establish an ASEAN economic community (AEC) 
by 2020. That deadline was later brought forward to 2015. The AEC aims to achieve a single 
market and production base in ASEAN with free flow of goods, services, investments, capital, 
and skilled labor.   
 
2.  Three major factors prompted ASEAN countries to advance the time frame to achieve 
the AEC. First was the need to maintain the centrality of ASEAN's role despite the proliferation 
of free trade agreements between ASEAN and its dialogue partner countries. Many of ASEAN’s 
free trade agreements aim at full liberalization of the markets before or by 2015; if the ASEAN 
market is not fully integrated before the realization of ASEAN free trade agreements, ASEAN's 
central role faces the risk of being eroded. Second is the genuine political desire of ASEAN 
leaders to expedite ASEAN economic integration and thereby take it to the next level. Third is 
the growing concern over the erosion of ASEAN's competitiveness vis-à-vis its key competitors, 
such as the People’s Republic of China and India.   
 
3.  ASEAN economic integration has been facilitated by a number of key initiatives. These 
include the ASEAN Free Trade Area (AFTA) based on the Common Effective Preferential Tariff 
Scheme, the ASEAN Framework Agreement on Services, and the ASEAN Investment Area. 
However, much remains to be done to move ASEAN economic integration forward.  
 
4.  The need to achieve a single market in ASEAN has become more pressing than ever. 
ASEAN member countries are fully aware that unless the realization of the AEC is expedited, 
ASEAN economic integration could lose its momentum. This regional technical assistance (TA) 
will examine the effectiveness and relevance of the goals and targets of the AEC in the context 
of the changing global, regional, and national economic landscape. The assessment will help 
identify policy measures for ASEAN countries to realize the establishment of the AEC by 2015.1   
 
II.  ISSUES 
5.  In November 2007, the ASEAN leaders adopted the ASEAN Economic Community 
Blueprint to facilitate the realization of the AEC. The blueprint contains clearly defined goals and 
targets for AEC operationalization. ASEAN has since made major strides toward these goals. 
The  adoption  of  the  ASEAN  Trade  in  Goods  Agreement  (ATIGA)  and  the  ASEAN 
Comprehensive  Investment  Agreement  (ACIA)—which  provide  specific  targets  for  ASEAN 
market integration, and investment liberalization and facilitation—are two of the most significant 
achievements in this regard.   
 
6.  ASEAN has now largely completed the easy phase of promoting integration through 
intraregional trade liberalization. As of 2009, zero tariffs applied to 64% of products in the 
Inclusion List of the ASEAN-6.2 The average tariff for ASEAN-6 under the Common Effective 
Preferential Tariffs Scheme has decreased to 1.5% from 12.8%, when the tariff-cutting exercise 
commenced in 1993. What remains are the economically sensitive sectors, such as agriculture, 
steel, and motor vehicles, and the more politically sensitive areas, such as reducing nontariff 
                                                 
1  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 16 August 2010. 
2  ASEAN-6 comprises Brunei Darussalam,  Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, and Thailand.

2   
measures;  pursuing  faster  trade  liberalization  of  services;  establishing  an  effective  dispute 
settlement mechanism; and reforming ASEAN’s institutional structure.  
 
7.  Moreover, the global economic landscape has also changed rapidly since the adoption 
of the AEC Blueprint, and all these changes are posing new and difficult challenges for ASEAN. 
The 2008 global financial crisis changed the balance of global economic power, and spurred 
massive  domestic  and  regional  policy  shifts.  Within  ASEAN,  the  crisis  has  produced 
contradictory responses. On the one hand, the crisis has put pressure on ASEAN countries to 
expedite ASEAN economic integration. On the other hand, some member countries have opted 
to rescind their commitments due to the impact of the global crisis.   
 
8.  Therefore ASEAN must thoroughly assess the effectiveness and relevance of the AEC 
goals  and  targets  in  the  context  of  this  changing  global,  regional,  and  national  economic 
landscape. The assessment will help identify policy measures for ASEAN countries to continue 
to expedite implementation of the AEC by 2015.    
 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.   Impact and Outcome 
9.  The overall objective of the study is to assess the effectiveness and relevance of the 
goals and targets of the AEC. It will examine impediments to building an AEC by 2015. In this 
respect, the study should materially extend, and provide additionality to Institute of Southeast 
Asian Studies (ISEAS) work documented in Brick by Brick: The Building of an ASEAN Economic 
Community.3 The study aims to (i) address major impediments to the AEC’s building blocks (i.e., 
AFTA, ASEAN Investment Area, and ASEAN Framework Agreement on Services); (ii) examine 
the  challenge  of  narrowing  the  economic  development  divide  within  ASEAN;  (iii)  examine 
whether the goal of building an economic community in an uncompromised and legitimate way 
can be realized given the current economic crisis and the relatively short timelines involved; and 
(iv) provide policy recommendations that could be implemented to expedite the integration 
process. In doing so, the TA should contribute to the timely achievement of the AEC (outcome), 
and ultimately help accelerate the process of ASEAN economic integration (impact).  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The assessment will look at the four pillars of the AEC and examine reforms for the 
ASEAN institutional architecture to support deeper economic integration. 
 
11.  Pillar 1: Achievement of a single market production base. The progress of achieving 
a single market and production base in ASEAN will be reviewed. The assessment will examine 
the challenges and issues that hinder AEC implementation, and include four background papers 
to examine the following challenges, among others: 
 
(i)  Nontariff  measures.  While  most  ASEAN  countries  have  complied  with  tariff 
reductions under AFTA, utilization of the common effective preferential tariffs has 
been relatively low. One of the main reasons could be nontariff measures, which 
persist and impede greater intra-ASEAN trade. Hence, effectively tackling nontariff 
                                                 
3  D. Hew, ed. 2007. Brick by Brick: The Building of an ASEAN Economic Community. Singapore: Institute of 
Southeast Asian Studies.

3
measures and trade barriers would be crucial if a fully functioning AFTA is to be 
feasible  by  2015.  This  paper  will  examine  the  status  of  the  use  of  nontariff 
measures in ASEAN and recommend measures to eliminate and/or remove barrier 
components of existing nontariff measures.    
(ii)  ASEAN dispute settlement. Despite the principles for dispute settlement set out 
in the 2004 ASEAN Protocol on Enhanced Dispute Settlement Mechanism and 
the 1996 ASEAN Protocol on Dispute Settlement Mechanism, ASEAN countries 
have yet to activate implementation of the protocol. This failure is due to many 
factors,  including  the  traditional  ASEAN  way  of  settling  disputes  in  a 
nonconfrontational manner. This paper will find ways to strengthen the ASEAN 
dispute settlement mechanism as an important component for building a rules-
based  structure  for  ASEAN  cooperation.  Lessons  from  other  regions  in 
establishing a dispute settlement mechanism will be presented. 
(iii)  Trade in services. Liberalization of services has been significantly bolder under 
the  ASEAN  Framework  Agreement  on  Services  than  under  the  World  Trade 
Organization’s General Agreement on Trade in Services (GATS). In 2003, ASEAN 
leaders adopted the application of the ASEAN-X formula, which aims to expedite 
liberalization in priority service sectors including air transport and tourism, health 
care, and e-ASEAN. However, the progress of ASEAN service liberalization is still 
slow. This paper will seek to determine why liberalization has been slow, and 
whether ASEAN should adopt a new approach to liberalizing trade in services in 
ASEAN.  
(iv)  Investment liberalization. The scope of the ASEAN Investment Area has placed 
too  much  emphasis  on  intraregional  foreign  direct  investment—it  prioritized 
investment  facilitation  and  provision  of  national  treatment  among  the  ASEAN 
partners. This strategy made very little sense, given that the bulk of foreign direct 
investment into the region comes from non-ASEAN economies like the United 
States, Japan, Europe, and increasingly, the People’s Republic of China and the 
Republic of Korea. To rectify this, a new ASEAN Investment Area platform in the 
form of the ASEAN Comprehensive Investment Agreement was signed in 2008. 
This  paper  will  examine  ASEAN  investment  liberalization  and  identify  ways  to 
promote the region’s dynamic involvement in regional and international production 
networks. 
 
12.  Pillar 2: Achievement of a highly competitive economic region. Three background 
papers will look at the following issues: 
 
(i)  developing regional guidelines on competition policy; 
(ii)  protecting intellectual property rights in ASEAN; and 
(iii)  promoting ASEAN connectivity: infrastructure development (transport, energy, 
telecommunications) and financing ASEAN infrastructure development.   
  
13.  Pillar  3:  Achievement  of  a  region  of  equitable  economic  development.  Three 
background papers will examine the following issues: 
  
(i)  implementing the ASEAN policy blueprint for small and medium-sized enterprise  
development; 
(ii)  operationalizing the concept of ASEAN (regional) public goods; and  
(iii)  developing  subregional  cooperation  programs  such  as  the  Greater  Mekong 
Subregion,  the  Brunei  Darussalam–Indonesia–Malaysia–Philippines  East

4   
ASEAN  Growth  Area  (BIMP-EAGA),  and  the  Indonesia–Malaysia–Thailand 
Growth Triangle (IMT-GT). 
 
14.  Pillar 4: Achievement of a region fully integrated into the global economy. One 
background paper will review the following issues: 
 
(i)  developing approaches and mechanisms to strengthen ASEAN’s role as a hub in 
East Asian integration;  
(ii)  promoting  wider  ASEAN  trade—many  ASEAN  trade  and  investment  facility 
programs, including capacity building, could be strengthened through synergy 
with similar programs of wider regional cooperation arrangements (e.g., ASEAN 
Plus Three, Six, Eight, and proposals on the Asia Economic Community, Asia 
Pacific free trade agreement);  
(iii)  developing  effective  and  open  regionalism  cooperation  schemes  with  other 
regions (e.g., North America, Europe, and Latin America); and 
(iv)  ensuring  compatibility  with  World  Trade  Organization  principles  by  pursuing 
means  to  multilateralize  preferential  accords  and  liberalize  rules-of-origin, 
thereby minimizing distortions and trade diversion. 
 
15.  ASEAN institutional architecture to support deeper economic integration. Deeper 
economic integration in ASEAN cannot be successfully achieved without establishing a stronger 
institutional structure. This paper will study the ASEAN institutional architecture and recommend 
how it should evolve in the future. The ”ASEAN Way” has traditionally entailed noninterference 
in the internal affairs of member states and consensus-based decision making. The paper will 
examine the ASEAN Charter and determine how ASEAN can move to a rules-based institution 
to oversee and coordinate the administrative tasks of establishing and setting policies.   
 
16.  The background papers reviewing the impact of nontariff measures, services, investment, 
and ASEAN trade will include business surveys as part of the overall analytical framework. A 
perception survey will be undertaken to seek the opinions of leaders and the public on ASEAN 
cooperation.  
 
17.  Reference materials for the background papers will include recent studies on ASEAN 
prepared by ADB, the ASEAN Secretariat and ISEAS. The findings of ADB's flagship studies—
Emerging  Asian  Regionalism:  A  Partnership  for  Shared  Prosperity,4 Infrastructure  for  a 
Seamless Asia,5 and Institutions for Integration: Toward an Asian Economic Community 6—will 
be useful reference materials. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $500,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on 
a  grant  basis  by  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund:  $300,000  from  TASF-IV  and 
$200,000 from TASF—other sources. The financing will cover the remuneration and travel 
expenses  of  international  and  national  consultants,  travel  expenses  of  conference  and 
workshop resource persons, report production, and other miscellaneous expenses. The cost 
estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
                                                 
4  ADB. 2008. Emerging Asian Regionalism: A Partnership for Shared Prosperity. Manila. 
5  ADB. 2009. Infrastructure for a Seamless Asia. Manila. 
6  ADB. 2010. Institutions for Integration: Toward an Asian Economic Community. Manila.

5
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  ADB will be the executing agency.  The TA will be implemented by the Office of Regional 
Economic Integration, in collaboration with ISEAS. The TA is expected to commence in August 
2010, and be completed by May 2012.  
 
20.  The TA will require one international principal consultant for 12 person-months, six 
international  trade  economists  for  12  person-months,  three  international  trade  lawyers  for  
6 person-months, an infrastructure consultant for 2 person-months, and a social development 
consultant for 2 person-months. The TA will also require 5 person-months of national consulting 
inputs. ADB will recruit the international consultants through single-source selection of a firm, in 
accordance with ADB's Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to 
time).  
 
21.  ISEAS, the firm being considered for this TA, is uniquely qualified for the planned scope 
of work, given its expertise in the ASEAN region. The primary focus of ISEAS and its work 
program is on ASEAN countries, including AEC-related research and policy work. ISEAS is the 
only institution in Asia with expertise required in ASEAN matters to undertake the kind of 
specialized and detailed work associated with the realization of the ASEAN AEC. It houses the 
ASEAN Center, which is headed by Rodolfo Severino, a former secretary-general of the ASEAN 
Secretariat. ISEAS is intimately familiar with the ASEAN Charter and ASEAN’s organizational 
structure and framework in general and the AEC Blueprint in particular, including its action plans 
and  target  dates  for  the  accomplishment  of  the  AEC.  In  addition,  ISEAS  has  a  thorough 
understanding of and experience in research relating to the accelerated realization of the AEC 
by the target date of 2015.  
 
22.  ISEAS will provide 34 person-months of international consulting services for the TA, 
which will cost approximately $340,000, covering remuneration, travel, and per diem.   
 
23,  Disbursements  under  the  TA  will  be  done  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
24.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis for 
Assessment  of  Impediments  and  Actions  Required  for  Achieving  an  ASEAN  Economic 
Community by 2015, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

6  Appendix 1

8  Appendix 3   
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The Institute of Southeast Asian Studies will provide the following consultants to conduct 
the study: 
 
2.  Principal consultant and team leader (international, 12 person-months). The consultant 
must be thoroughly familiar with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and its 
programs for regional economic integration, the programs’ possibilities and limitations, and their 
prospects for achievement and the constraints that need to be overcome, particularly in terms of 
realizing the ASEAN Economic Community (AEC) by 2015. Knowledge of the issues to be covered 
in the background papers is essential.  
 
3.  The consultant must have (i) detailed knowledge of ASEAN’s institutional structure and 
operations  demonstrated  by  refereed  publications;  (ii)  extensive  experience  working  in  a 
multilateral, intergovernmental setting; (iii) awareness of ASEAN’s nature and the character and 
history of its member countries; (iv) extensive networking with policy makers and opinion-making 
research institutions in the region; and (v) familiarity with policies and procedures of the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB). Previous ADB assignments would be an advantage. 
 
4.  The principal consultant (team leader) will be engaged to 
(i)  prepare the background paper on the ASEAN institutional architecture; 
(ii)  guide and coordinate the work of the other international consultants; 
(iii)  review and comment on all studies to be carried out under the technical assistance; 
(iv)  ensure the analytical depth, quality, and publishable standard of the studies; 
(v)  participate in the national and/or regional workshops to be organized, as necessary; 
and 
(vi)  undertake other tasks as appropriate and required by ADB. 
 
5.   Six trade economists (international, 2 person-months each). The trade economists will 
prepare six papers covering the following topics: (i) nontariff measures (pillar 1); (ii) ASEAN service 
liberalization (pillar 1); (iii) ASEAN investment (pillar 1); (iv) ASEAN small and medium-sized 
enterprises  (pillar  3);  (v)  subregional  cooperation  in  ASEAN  such  as  the  Greater  Mekong 
Subregion,  the  Brunei  Darussalam–Indonesia–Malaysia–Philippines  East  ASEAN  Growth  Area 
(BIMP-EAGA), and the Indonesia–Malaysia–Thailand Growth Triangle (IMT-GT) (pillar 3); and  
(vi) ASEAN integration with the global economy. 
 
6.  The international trade economists must (i) be specialists in ASEAN regional economic 
integration; (ii) have knowledge and understanding of the issues involved in its targets, progress, 
and challenges; (iii) be well acquainted with ASEAN’s macroeconomy; (iv) have specialization in 
services and/or investments and trade facilitation, as required; (v) have published refereed journal 
articles, monographs, or chapters in books in these areas; (vi) have experience working with 
multilateral agencies, regional bodies, and national governments in Southeast Asia; (vii) have a full 
appreciation and understanding of realities on the ground; and (viii) have a pragmatic vision of 
ASEAN’s capability to achieve milestones with regard to the AEC in the next 5 years and beyond. 
 
7.  Three  international  trade  lawyers  (international,  2  person-months  each).  The  trade 
lawyers will prepare three background papers on (i) the ASEAN dispute settlement mechanism 
(pillar  1),  (ii)  ASEAN  competition  policy  (pillar  2),  and  (iii)  ASEAN  intellectual  property  rights  
(pillar 2).

Appendix 3    9
8.  The  international  trade  lawyers  must  (i)  be  specialists  in  ASEAN  regional  economic 
integration; (ii) have knowledge and understanding of the issues involved in its targets, progress, 
and challenges; (iii) be well-acquainted with ASEAN’s legal systems and have specialization in 
World  Trade  Organization  legal  frameworks;  (iv)  have  experience  working  with  multilateral 
agencies, regional bodies, and national governments in Southeast Asia; (v) have a full appreciation 
and  understanding  of  realities  on  the  ground;  and  (vi)  have  a  pragmatic  vision  of  ASEAN’s 
capability to achieve milestones with regard to the AEC in the next 5 years and beyond. 
 
9.  Infrastructure consultant (international, 2 person-months). The consultant will prepare the 
paper  on  ASEAN  connectivity  (pillar  2).  The  consultant  must  (i)  be  a  specialist  in  ASEAN 
infrastructure cooperation; (ii) have knowledge and understanding of the issues involved in its 
targets,  progress,  and  challenges;  (iii)  be  well  acquainted  with  ASEAN  systems;  (iv)  have 
specialization  in  ASEAN  infrastructure  issues;  (v)  have  experience  working  with  multilateral 
agencies,  regional  bodies,  and  national  governments  in  Southeast  Asia;  (vi)  have  a  full 
appreciation and understanding of realities on the ground; and (vii) have a pragmatic vision of 
ASEAN’s capability to achieve milestones with regard to the AEC in the next 5 years and beyond. 
10.  One social development consultant (international, 2 person-months). The consultant will 
prepare a paper to identify ways to translate the concept of “ASEAN (regional) public goods” into 
practice (pillar 3). The consultant must (i) be a specialist in ASEAN sociodevelopment cooperation; 
(ii)  have  knowledge  and  understanding  of  the  issues  involved  in  its  targets,  progress,  and 
challenges;  (iii)  be  well  acquainted  with  ASEAN  systems;  (iv)  have  specialization  in  social 
development issues; (v) have experience working with multilateral agencies, regional bodies, and 
national governments in Southeast Asia; (vi) have a full appreciation and understanding of realities 
on the ground; and (vi) have a pragmatic vision of ASEAN’s capability to achieve milestones with 
regard to the AEC in the next 5 years and beyond. 
11.  Economics  editor  (national,  3-person  months).  The  economics  editor  must  have 
knowledge of the ASEAN community. In addition he/she must have a good knowledge of current 
issues  and  developments  in  ASEAN  economic  integration;  and  have  experience  working  in 
macroeconomic policy research, in government, academia, or international organizations. Specific 
functions will include the following: 
(i)  review, comment on, and edit the international economists’ draft papers and other 
documents and papers; 
(ii)  ensure consistency, coherence, readability, and the highest publication standards; 
and 
(iii)  carry out any other tasks as appropriate and as required by Office of Regional 
Economic Integration and the principal consultant (team leader). 
 
12.  Workshop facilitator (national, 2-person months). The workshop facilitator should be a 
specialist with extensive experience in organizing and conducting national and regional workshops 
and conferences. Specific functions will include the following: 
(i)  provide  technical,  administrative,  and  logistic  support  for  the  coordination  and 
efficient implementation of activities in different aspects of the project;  
(ii)  help organize and facilitate workshops and other meetings; 
(iii)  undertake  any  other  work  as  assigned  and  required  by  the  Office  of  Regional 
Economic Integration and the principal consultant (team leader).

author_page:
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
AEC  –  ASEAN economic community 
ASEAN  –  Association of Southeast Asian Nations  
ISEAS  –  Institute of Southeast Asian Studies  
TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Regional—Research and development technical assistance  
(R–RDTA) 
Targeting classification  –  General intervention 
Sectors (subsectors)  –  Industry and trade (trade and services), public sector management  
(economic and public affairs management) 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Regional cooperation and integration (trade and investments); 
economic growth (promoting macroeconomic stability, widening 
access to markets and economic opportunities) 
Location impact  –  Rural (low), urban (medium), national (high), regional (high)  
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to US dollars. 
 
 
Head  S. Madhur, Senior Director and Officer-in-Charge, Office of Regional 
Economic Integration (OREI) 
   
Team leader  J. Menon, Principal Economist, OREI 
Team member  W. Paz, Senior Economics Officer, OREI 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.
